#Text=[0105] The modified reactor is generally divided into four zones in which each zone temperature can be individually controlled.
#Text=The reactor also has three separate delivery tubes for the reactant gases and diluents.
#Text=Nitrogen or hydrogen is used as a diluent and carrier gases to NH.sub.3 and HCl.
#Text=Nitrogen is sent through the middle tube where it acts as a downstream gas sheath to prevent the premixing of the GaCl and NH.sub.3 before the gases contact the substrate surface.
#Text=The texturing of the GaN layer can be attributed to the etching effects of HCl.
#Text=For example, texturing occurs as HCl etches Ga from the surface of the growing layer.
#Text=HCl also etches defective GaN at the boundary domains of the first layer.
#Text=The HCl concentration of the modified HVPE process is substantially higher than that of typical deposition processes where texturing is avoided.

#Text=[0106] The textured GaN templates can be grown under high growth rate conditions ranging from about 30 to 200 .mu.m per hr that is controlled by the flow ratio of NH.sub.3 to the group III precursor.
#Text=The flow ratio is typically about 300 to 10.
#Text=The template's growth is performed by pretreatment of the substrate with GaCl gas or by exposing the sapphire surface to ammonia for a short time (nitridation) at 1000.degree.
#Text=C. followed by the growth of a thin GaN buffer layer from 550.degree.
#Text=C. to 650.degree.
#Text=C.
#Text=The growth area can then be ramped to about 1070.degree.
#Text=C. for high temperature epilayer growth of GaN.
#Text=The substrate can also be pretreated prior to growth with sputtered zinc oxide.
#Text=The usual thickness of the zinc oxide is from about 500 .ANG. to 1500 .ANG..
#Text=Growth of the template is then performed by heating the chamber to the growth temperature and flowing the reactant gases in order to initiate growth.
#Text=[0107] MOCVD is the method currently used by industry for the growth of GaN-based LEDs.
#Text=This method produces nitrides by the reaction of Group III-alkyls (e.g.
#Text=(CH3) 3Ga or (C2H5) 3Ga) with NH3.
#Text=One problem with this method is the cost associated with the high consumption of NH3.
#Text=Growth of GaN films at 1 .mu.
#Text=/hr requires 5 to 10 lpm of NH3.
#Text=[0108] The MBE method forms III-nitrides by the reaction of Group III elements with molecular nitrogen activated by various forms of RF or microwave plasmas.
#Text=An alternative approach is the reaction of Group III elements with ammonia on a heated substrate.
#Text=The Group III elements can be either evaporated from effusion cells or provided in the form of Group III alkyls.
#Text=It is generally believed that products produced by the MBE method are more expensive due to throughput issues.
#Text=However, in the growth of nitrides, a significant part of the cost is determined by the consumption of nitrogen precursors.
#Text=During MBE growth of nitride devices, one employs approximately 1 to 50 sccm of nitrogen or ammonia, which is several orders of magnitude less than what is employed during MOCVD growth.
#Text=This together with the fact that MBE production equipment employs multi-wafer deposition systems makes the MBE method attractive for the development of inexpensive nitride devices.
#Text=InGaN-based laser diodes have recently been produce by the MBE method [Hooper et al., Electronics Letters, Vol. 40, 8 Jan. 2004].
#Text=[0109] In one aspect of the invention, the surface of a GaN template is randomly textured.
#Text=Appropriate random surface texture can be produced by any suitable mechanical or chemical techniques, including modified HVPE.
#Text=In modified HVPE, the surface texture of the GaN template can be controlled by varying the group-III to group-V ratio.

#Text=For example, using a molar ratio of NH.sub.3 to HCl of 5:1 to 10:1 yields randomly textured GaN templates by modified HVPE, whereas conventional HVPE using higher ratios such as 20:1 to 50:1 or higher yields smooth templates.
#Text=Other methods to produce randomly textured GaN templates include incomplete nitridation of a substrate such as a sapphire wafer, or using an extremely thin GaN buffer.
#Text=Growth of GaN at high temperatures under nitrogen rich conditions can also yield randomly textured GaN templates by the MBE method.
#Text=For example, using a molar ratio of Ga/N of less than 1 produces randomly textured GaN templates.
#Text=Using a molar ratio of Ga/N of more than 1 results in smooth GaN templates.
